content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

```julia
function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    new_col = Vector{String}(undef, length(df))
    for (i, dt) in enumerate(df.dt)
        year, month = DateTime(dt).sectors[1:2]
        ym = string(year, "%02d", month)
        new_col[i] = ym
    end
    return new_col
end
```

This function takes a `DataFrame` with a column named `dt` and returns a new column named `ym` containing the year and month of each date in "yyyymm" format. It does this by extracting the year and month from each DateTime object using the `DateTime(::Date)` constructor to ensure consistent formatting, then concatenating them into a string with leading zeros for the month if necessary. Finally, it returns the new column as a vector of strings.
